key_points: President Joe Biden signed a $1.9 trillion Covid-19 economic relief package into law.
Biden highlighted that the legislation aims to rebuild the country's backbone and support working and middle-class individuals.
The relief package was Biden's top legislative priority since taking office in January.
The signing was moved up a day earlier than planned, with a celebration with Congressional leaders to follow.
The plan includes $1,400 stimulus payments for most households, a $300 boost to weekly jobless benefits, and an expanded child tax credit.
It also allocates $350 billion for state and local aid, funds for K-12 schools, small businesses, and Covid-19 vaccine distribution.
White House Press Secretary Jen Psaki announced that stimulus checks could start appearing in bank accounts as early as the coming weekend.
Biden to deliver his first prime-time address marking the one-year anniversary of the Covid-19 pandemic shutdown.
The address will acknowledge the pandemic's impact and outline steps to combat the virus, offering a hopeful vision for the future.
The relief package provides $14 billion for Covid-19 vaccine research, distribution, and administration efforts.
spokespersons: Joe Biden (President of the United States)
Ron Klain (White House Chief of Staff)
